instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2327: What is 820-2327? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Hello,

new member from Greece and an absolute beginner.

Thank you Louis, Duke, and the rest of the board for making this forum available to the world.

I bought a complete Macbook Pro 15 late 2008 cheap on ebay with one USB not working. Measured around, replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q4690</TRANSISTOR>, nothing. <CAPACITOR>C4616</CAPACITOR> was shorted to ground. Replaced that, still no USB.

Next day I plugged in the charger and got no green light! I thought it would be something easy. I also have a donor board with onewire working. Great help! I measured <RESISTOR>R6917</RESISTOR> pin1 16.82V pin2 0V, healthy board shows pin2 7.42V. <RESISTOR>R6917</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6918</RESISTOR> measure 140K, schematic says 270K. What the heck?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
What is pin 4 of <CHIP>U6915</CHIP>? If it is high I suspect a dead <CHIP>U6915</CHIP>. This happened because of plugging in the magsafe on a bare connector and not aligning it, so onewire shorts to 18V bus.
You cannot expect a resistor that is in circuit to measure the correct value. It could be lower because of other stuff in parallel with it. If it measured higher then there could be a problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Duke, an early bird, aren't you?

<CHIP>U6915</CHIP> pin4 is 7.32V, on healthy it is 0V. Also, pin3 is 0V, on healthy it is 3.29V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Or late ;)

<CHIP>U6915</CHIP> seems dead for the reason I mentioned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Thank you, Duke.

I'll replace <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> and get back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U6915</CHIP>, got exactly the same values on all pins. Could the donor be bad, should I try with another donor chip from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2327</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> or could it be something else?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Hmm, it could be dead <TRANSISTOR>Q6915</TRANSISTOR> pulling up pin 4 of <CHIP>U6915</CHIP>. Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q6915</TRANSISTOR> and measure pin 4 again.

Edit:
Actually that is not possible if pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6917</RESISTOR> is 0V. Measure voltages on all pins of <CHIP>U6915</CHIP>.

You are using a known good magsafe board I hope?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Took another <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> from a board with green light but bad GPU and I have a green light ! ! !

Should I proceed in this post to solve the original problem of the board that was 1 bad USB, or should I open a new post?

Also, should I ultrasonic the board again to get rid of the flux in that area or should I use alcohol and a soft brush? Does ultrasonic cleaning multiple times wear the board out?

Thank you, thank you, thank you Duke!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Does the port have 5V on it? Plug in HDD and see if it spins up. If that is ok then measure on diode mode both data lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: I am using a genuine magsafe 85W. I replaced L4610, measured for short to ground on all for pins, they're all OK. Plugging in a mouse does nothing, but when I unplug it red light flashes for a second and I confirmed with a multimeter, I get 5V. Something wrong with the MCP I guess... Will I harm the board if I ultrasonic it a second time?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Measure on diode mode on the data pins, what do you get? If they are both the same it should be ok. Remove <DIODE>D4610</DIODE> and see if it works, could be bad.

I assume only 1 USB is not working or are both dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Replaced <DIODE>D4610</DIODE> and BAM, I have my USB working now. The other USB was fine. Should I re-ultrasonic or will I harm the board?

Thank you for your help, Duke!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Why clean it? Just replace <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> also to prevent it coming back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> has not enough space as the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> has to replace <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> with a proper large one. Does Luis have a video on this model?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Solder GND side, the cap will sticking up a bit over the FET. Then a bit of wire to the coil.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Replaced the <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> cap as instructed. Tested the board, all done. Thanks a million!
